reasoning: The critique targets a real feature of the essay—its explicit expected-value/gamble framing and its inclusion of highly speculative “cosmic stakes” examples (acausal trade, simulations, infinite value)—but this is not very central to the essay’s core claim that near-best futures are a narrow target on many plausible moral views. If the critique landed fully, it would mostly undermine prudential/communication choices (and potentially the essay’s net impact), not the main descriptive/philosophical conclusion. The argument’s force is moderate: memetic weaponization and ‘Pascal’s mugging’ style laundering of reckless actions is plausible, and the essay does supply rhetorical material that could be misused, but the critique is speculative about adversaries and decision-makers, doesn’t show this is likely net-increasing in catastrophe risk, and doesn’t directly rebut the underlying “fussiness/fragility” arguments. Most of what it says is reasonable (though not strongly evidenced), it is fairly clear and focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Framing speculative risks as live threats enables memetic exploitation
